                A U.S. Capitol Police officer stands guard. | Getty

            By 
Seung Min Kim

11/16/15 12:22 PM EST
Capitol Police are bolstering security around the Capitol following the terrorist attacks in Paris and are urging lawmakers and congressional staffers to take “simple precautions,” such as traveling through the tunnels that connect the Capitol to the House and Senate office buildings. 
The notice from the Capitol Police Board stresses that there are currently no specific threat against the Capitol. But officials note that the Hill complex will “always be an appealing target.”
Story Continued Below
“Today's threat environment dictates that we operate at a high level of vigilance and employ agile and flexible tactics to ensure the safety of the Legislative Branch against persistent dangers,” the note, sent Monday morning, says. “As with many law enforcement agencies around the nation, the [U.S. Capitol Police] has increased visibility in a number of areas.”
In addition to taking tunnels to go between buildings in the Capitol complex, officials, “out of an abundance of caution,” are also urging staffers to keep their office informed of where they are. 
The message was sent from Senate sergeant-at-arms Frank Larkin, House sergeant-at-arms Paul Irving, Architect of the Capitol Stephen Ayers, and Capitol Police Chief Kim Dine. 
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Security heightened around the Capitol
